title: demolition-looms-for-historic-galashiels-church
story:
THE death knell has been sounded for a Galashiels church after Scottish Borders councillors voted to allow its demolition.
St Aidan&rsquos Church, in Gala Park, is set to face the wrecking ball after the owners, Cumbria-based Book Development, concluded that renovating the B-listed Gothic church would be uneconomical.
At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council&rsquos planning and building standards committee on Monday, principal planning officer Barry Fotheringham said demolition was the only economically viable option left.
He said: &ldquoThe building is not physically incapable of repair, therefore the overriding principle that needs to be satisfied is one of economic viability.
&ldquoThis application is supported by feasibility reports and valuations which estimate the building is beyond the point of economic repair.
&ldquoVarious options have been explored, including the conversion of the church into residential properties, though this would incur a loss of &pound700,000, based on 2018 costs.
&ldquoAn alternative scheme for a development which would retain the front facade of the church and the spire was also evaluated, and this would potentially result in a loss of around &pound1m.
&ldquoThe applicant provided subsequent figures that would need to be invested in order to make a profit. &nbsp
&ldquoThese assessments conclude that in order to make a reasonable profit, 29 units would be required on site, with 24 units behind the facade and five on the site behind the church.
&ldquoIt is accepted that not all options have been explored, but it is reasonable to assume that the applicant has demonstrated that a substantial and likely inappropriate development would be required to make the scheme viable.
&ldquoI am satisfied that the viability argument has been met.
Speaking in favour of allowing the demolition, East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing said: &ldquoI just think this is really, really sad to lose this fabulous building. It depresses me, but I can&rsquot see any other option but to approve this as pretty much all options have been reasonably explored, so it&rsquos with a heavy heart that I vote with the officer&rsquos recommendation.
Galashiels councillor Sandy Aitchison also supported the recommendation to allow the demolition but said he would be sad to see it go, adding: &ldquoThere&rsquos a huge emotional issue in terms of buildings and things which are of historic signicance.
&ldquoI worry about the future of built environments. Take our capital city for example. There are some huge historical buildings, and the upkeep of these buildings is hugely expensive.
&ldquoWhat are we going to do with them? They can&rsquot all be Wetherspoons.
&ldquoIt&rsquos a sad reflection of society that many have gone that way. I prefer to see it demolished rather than see it degraded, and that&rsquos a sad thing to say.
&ldquoI just want to stop the continuous pain of it degrading and just see it go, so I&rsquom happy to support the demolition, but it is tinged with regret and sadness.

title: pop-up-bobs-are-putting-brakes-on-borders-speedsters
story:
POP-UP &lsquoBobs&rsquo are helping improve road safety in the Borders, according to police chiefs.
Since the start of the year, cardboard cut outs of officers have been deployed in speeding hotspots around the region.
And bosses at Police Scotland say they are having a positive impact.
Speaking at Friday&rsquos meeting of the Police, Fire and Rescue and Safer Communities Board, Chief Inspector Andy McLean said: &ldquoRoad safety is an issue which is very close to my heart.
&ldquoWe have a number of projects in place to help make our roads safer.
&ldquoThe uptake in the Drivewise scheme has been signicant, which is great because it helps people improve their driving skills.
&ldquoThe pop-up Bobs have also been very well received. They allow us to put a cardboard officer in areas where speeding is a problem.
&ldquoThis means we can station a real officer just down the road, to stop drivers breaking the limit.
&ldquoThere is also a lot of work ongoing to help protect &lsquovulnerable&rsquo road users, such as horse riders and cyclists. We will often put a plain-clothed officer on a bike or horse and an unmarked car just behind to ensure drivers are passing safely.
&ldquoWe have issued tickets to people for careless driving as part of this initiative.
There were 17 people killed or seriously injured on Borders roads between April and June &ndash one more than the same period last year.
But the number of those suffering minor injuries fell by 26 per cent.
Ch Insp McLean added: &ldquoBeing in the Borders, there are a few incidents which involve motorbikes, as this area is a magnet for bikers.
&ldquoIt is a great place they come to enjoy the scenery and the roads, but unfortunately  you come off, there is not much to protect you.
&ldquoWe will continue to look at more education initiatives to help people improve their driving skills in the Borders, but the dficulty is that some people involved in the incidents have been from outwith the area.
&ldquoOne positive to note is that we have seen a decrease in the number of over 65s involved in accidents.
&ldquoIt seems to be the middle-age band who have been in the most.

title: delight-as-innerleithen-post-office-is-returned-to-sender
story:
RED letter day finally arrived for Innerleithen this week with the  of a full time Post Office. Before the official opening, our reporter Hilary Scott met up with Susan Meikle and Hazel Millen, owners of the Allotment, who stepped in to save the day following the closure of the previous Post Office on the High Street.
It wasn&rsquot ever their dream to be postal mistresses. Susan and Hazel were content running their successful store, which has been selling fresh fruit and vegetables, cheese, wholefoods, jams and chutney since 2011.
They had always been open to suggestions from residents on new products and ideas &ndash creating a monthly cheese tasting evening, and a popular home delivery service.
When news hit the town of the Post Office closure in February last year, the community fought a hard campaign to see its full-time service .
The impact of the closure was felt by the Allotment and other High Street businesses. Susan explained: &ldquoWhen it closed, a lot of people who previously used the Post Office started going out of the town and naturally doing their shopping elsewhere. It hit Innerleithen hard.
The pair had previously laughed off any suggestions by locals that they could house the Post Office within their store.
But one evening in late December, something moved Susan to click a link online to find out more information &ndash and from this very moment, the revival of the Post Office began.
No-one had officially approached them to take on the Post Office, so when asked what moved them to send the application, Susan and Hazel looked at one another and mused: &ldquoYou could call it insanity!
It wasn&rsquot easily signed, sealed and delivered. There were many loop holes to jump through, including applications, interviews and trips to Glasgow for training, before they could start running Innerleithen&rsquos new service from their premises.
And although Susan and Hazel say they will not financially benefit by taking on this new responsibility, they feel the gain is retaining a vital service for the people of Innerleithen.
Variety is the spice of le, and for the Allotment owners and their two hardworking members of staff Leanne and Susan, they&rsquoll be juggling more than apples and pears on occasions. &ldquoI hope people give us a chance. It is going to be a challenge running the Post Office and serving our valued customers, added Susan. &ldquoThere are going to be times that there will be a queue and we would appreciate people&rsquos patience. We are new to this. It might take a little longer for us to do things, but it will be done right.
I on the other-hand like to think that a little festive magic played its part in the happy ending to this tale, and somewhere in this quaint town, the one request on someone&rsquos Christmas list was that the community didn&rsquot lose its postal service.
And it wasn&rsquot delivered by a postman, or a man with a white beard wearing a red suit and black boots. It was answered and delivered by these two brave and ambitious local ladies, who with the community at heart, saved Innerleithen&rsquos Post Office.

title: photos-group-of-flamingo-chicks-hatch-in-oxton
story:
A GROUP of flamingo chicks have hatched at a Borders conservation centre.
News of the arrival of the Chilean flamingo flock was confirmed by Bird Gardens Scotland.
The newborns&nbspwill form part of a new visitor attraction in Oxton, near Lauder.
The chicks hatched from eggs laid by the established Chilean flamingo flock at Chester Zoo.
The flock at Chester had a breeding success earlier in the summer, leading to a number of surplus eggs.
The eggs in question were incubated by the Bird Section in Chester prior to being carefully transported to Bird Gardens Scotland in Oxton, to hatch.
Its not been confirmed how many chicks there are.
Following on from hatching, the eggs will take 30 days to develop into healthy flamingo chicks, also known as flaminglings.
Mark Haillay of Bird Gardens Scotland said: &ldquoIt&rsquos an incredible moment when you first hear a flamingo egg grunt at you and you know that within 48 hours there will be a chick asleep, resting after its epic journey from inside the egg out into the world.
Like many other types of bird, flaminglings have an egg-tooth on the tip of their beak which they use to gradually scratch and chip away at the shell creating an opening large enough for them to wriggle free of the shell and out into the world.
The flaminglings will be hand reared in Oxton, fed every two hours round the clock with a specialist liquidised diet fed through a syringe.
This mimics the beak-to-beak feeding which would occur in parent reared birds parent flamingos produce a rich saliva  and dribble this into the chick&rsquos beak providing all the water, nutrients and energy they need to grow and stay healthy.
Mark added: &ldquoIt&rsquos incredibly exciting to think these little balls of grey fluff will grow to be majestic flamingos. Rearing flaminglings is hard work - it takes the energy of both parent flamingos to rear just one chick. We&rsquore hoping to rear more than ten chicks each year from surplus eggs.
Bird Gardens Scotland was established in 2017 and is developing into a unique visitor attraction outside Oxton.
Planning Permission was granted earlier this year to create a Visitor Centre which will welcome visitors, provide an opportunity for people to learn about the birds we work with and enjoy coffee and cake at the attraction.

title: bell-honour-for-sheep-breeder-james
story:
A VETERAN sheep breeder from the Borders will ring the bell to start Europe's biggest ram sale later this month.
James Jeffrey is set to be honoured for a letime&rsquos commitment to the region&rsquos sheep industry next Friday by signalling the start of the Closamectin Border Union Ram Sales in Kelso.
James first attended Kelso Ram Sales in 1942 at the age of 15, when he was responsible for selling the family farm&rsquos Half Bred tups.
His son, John now manages the family business, which operates from Kersknowe near Kelso and includes the oldest registered flock of Border Leicester sheep.
James told us: &ldquoI&rsquom hugely honoured to have been asked to ring the bell to start the sale this year.
"The Kelso Ram Sales are a highlight in the farming calendar, both for our family, and for the industry as a whole.
"Despite many changes over the years, they have held their position within the industry and I&rsquom greatly looking forward to playing such an important role at this year&rsquos event.
Dating back to 1838, Europe&rsquos biggest one-day ram sale has seen 5,458 entries this year be sold across 15 rings by seven dferent auctioneering companies.
The event, whose main sponsors are Closamectin and Rumenco, is a huge undertaking and includes 10 marquees with over 178,000 sq ft of space to house the sale rings and sheep.
Mags Clark from the Border Union Agricultural Society will be at the helm for the first time this year.
She said: "The official 10am ringing of the bell to mark the start of the Kelso Ram Sales is one of the event&rsquos most important traditions and we felt that this year, the honour of starting proceedings should go to someone who has made a signicant contribution to the sheep industry in the region.
"James&rsquo family has been selling sheep at this event since around 1900 and he&rsquos a past President of the Border Leicester Sheep Society with a huge commitment to the industry, so we believe he&rsquos the ideal person for the job this year.
A total of 18 dferent breeds will be represented at the 181st Ram Sales.
Mags is hopeful that last year&rsquos record-breaking turnover will be exceeded.
She added: "The sales turnover for the event passed the &pound3 million mark for the first time last year, with the sale average also breaking the &pound700 barrier.
"The quality of the animals on sale here is always second to none so we&rsquore greatly looking forward welcoming buyers and sellers from across the UK and Ireland for this signicant event in the country&rsquos agricultural calendar.

title: jobs-lost-at-galashiels-construction-firm
story:
A TOTAL of 17 jobs are being lost in Galashiels and Livingston with the restructuring of a major construction company.
Esh Construction, which recently completed the new health centre in Galashiels as well as social housing projects in Hawick, announced the redundancies this week.
Esh had offices in Carlisle, Kendal and Earlston, before expanding with the creation of new offices in Livingston and Galashiels.
The company which employs around 450 workers carried out a &ldquocomprehensive strategic review of its operations in Scotland earlier this year.
And it resulted in 17 posts being made redundant.
Esh Construction&rsquos regional director for Scotland, Gerard McMahon, said: &ldquoEsh Construction&rsquos Board has recently initiated a comprehensive strategic review of its operations in Scotland. An early outcome from this review is a restructuring of some of the activities carried out by our Livingston and Galashiels offices.
"Regrettably this has led to some redundancies as we seek to streamline our processes and drive efficiencies.
&ldquoWe remain fully committed to our projects and are currently looking to leverage the considerable range of resources available at our central HQ to ensure we deliver projects in line with our client&rsquos expectations.
&ldquoWe are offering support to those colleagues affected by these changes, we thank them for their contribution to the Esh Group and wish them the very best for the future.

title: innerleithen-pipe-band-championships-to-be-held-on-saturday
story:
THE best&nbspPipe Bands from all over South East Central Scotland will descend on Innerleithen this Saturday  for the annual Innerleithen Pipe Band Championships.
The event will be held in the grounds of St Ronan&rsquos School in&nbspInnerleithen, with the bands battling it out&nbspto see who will triumph supreme.
Allan Johnston, the Secretary of St Ronan&rsquos Piping Society, who runs the competition told us:&nbsp&ldquoThe contest will feature over 25 performances with bands from Grades 2, 3, 4, Novice Juvenile and a Juvenile and Adult Drum Majors completion.
&ldquoThere will be something for everyone and at the end of the day we will be handing out a fine array of trophies and prize money amounting to over &pound2000 to the successful bands.
In addition to the fine Pipe Band music there will be an array of stalls, a face painter, pony rides, snack bar, plus&nbspa bar.
Allan added: &ldquoOur Chieftain this year needs no introduction to the Innerleithen music scene David Lindsay, Davy to his many friends has been involved the St Ronan&rsquos Silver Band for over 53 years.
And David Lindsay spoke of his honour of the role as Chetain.
He said:&nbsp&ldquoMusic has been a large part of my le, but as part of a dferent genre to pipe bands.
&ldquoI am an avid member of the now world-famous St. Ronan&rsquos Silver Band based here in Innerleithen, however this has never dampened my enjoyment of pipe bands and I particularly enjoy the massed bands elements of Games Week.
&ldquoI am highly honoured to be Chieftain of this year&rsquos Innerleithen Pipe Band Championships and I would like to commend the outstanding efforts of the Piping Society who have built up this competition to be one of the most highly regarded competitions in the piping and drumming calendar.
David will take over the Chain of Office from 2015 Chieftain, Norman Scott who is standing in for last year&rsquos Chieftain John Connor.&nbsp
David will take the salute from the massed bands along with a prizegiving at 4.30pm and  and will later&nbspbe saluted by the participating bands as they parade at around&nbsp5.15pm from St. Ronan&rsquos Road, Queen Street, Horsbrugh Street and High Street to fall out in Hall Street.
As an added attraction to this year&rsquos event the RSPBA Lothian &amp Borders Branch will be crowning their 
Champion of Champions
&nbspthe bands who have won overall during the competitive season.
Entry to the event will be &pound3 per person , &pound1 for children over five years. Entry is free for children under five, and children in buggies.
Parking will be &pound2&nbspper car.

title: fair-start-scotland-helps-people-to-find-work
story:
Help is at hand for Borderers looking for work.
Fair Start Scotland is Scotland&rsquos new devolved employment support service. It is focused on supporting unemployed people who have challenges in accessing the labour market for whom work is a realistic prospect.
Launched in April this year, it is an example of one of the first uses of newly devolved powers under the 2016 Scotland Act. The service will run until 2023 and aims to provide tailored, flexible and person-centred support to at least 38,000 people across Scotland who want help to find work, and stay in work.
Participation is voluntary so won&rsquot affect existing benefits or be driven by fear of benefit sanctions.
The service is based on partnership and joint working between the Scottish Government, and the public, third and private sectors to deliver better outcomes for people seeking employment support.
Delivery is over nine geographic areas and reflect local area economies, meeting the needs of employers, disabled people
and those at risk of long-term unemployment.
To check whether you are eligible, you can contact the service provider in your area at www.mygov.scot/fairstart.

title: lamont-calls-on-pm-to-push-for-borders-railway-extension
story:
PRIME Minister Theresa May has been urged to lend her support to the campaign to extend the Borders Railway to Hawick.
Local MP John Lamont raised the need for a continuation of the line to Hawick and beyond during Prime Minister's Questions.
Responding, Mrs May said she 'understood the importance' of the campaign and promised that the Scottish and UK Governments would work in partnership to deliver economic growth for the region.
During the exchange, Mr Lamont said that extending the railway to Hawick, Newcastleton and on to Carlisle would 'greatly enhance economic activity in the region and would be a powerful example of cross border cooperation between Scotland&rsquos two governments'.
He urged the Prime Minister to ensure that the proposed Borderlands Growth Deal, which is currently being developed by five cross-border local authorities, supported the campaign to extend the Borders Railway.
Mr Lamont told us: &ldquoI was pleased to be able to raise the campaign to bring the Borders Railway to Hawick directly with the Prime Minister.
&ldquoBringing the line to Hawick would be transformational for the town and although it is not going to happen overnight, I am confident that we have an opportunity to push the campaign on to the next stage.
"Bringing the Borders Railway to Hawick, Newcastleton and Carlisle is exactly the type of project which Borderlands should be promoting. It would be a massive boost for Hawick and the rest of the Borders and would improve connectivity in the region, particularly  the line was to link up to the West Coast.
&ldquoI am determined to continue to pursue this issue and make sure that Borderlands moves this vital project forward.

title: cops-team-up-with-borders-banks-to-stop-con-artists
story:
POLICE chiefs in the Borders have teamed up with local banks to stop conmen swindling vulnerable people.
Officers have taken the initiative following an increasing number of reports of pensioners being conned out of large sums of cash. And it has already seen positive results.
At last Friday&rsquos meeting of the Police, Fire and Rescue and Safer Communities Board at Newtown, chief inspector Andy McLean revealed a number of measures had been put in place in a bid to stop the scams.
He said: &ldquoWe have put a lot of focus into doorstep crime. There are many measures we have taken to make people more aware of this type of crime.
&ldquoFor example we are using Facebook and social media more, as well as posting the incidents on SB Alerts.
Ch insp McLean told the meeting bank staff had been briefed on what to do  they think something is not quite right. He added: &ldquoWe have been doing a lot of work with the banks in the area recently.
&ldquoAnd, to be honest, they have been brilliant. They have already stopped many vulnerable people taking big sums of money out of their accounts.
&ldquoThe bank will then phone us, and when we turn up the customer is normally still there, but the scammers have gone. However this initiative has stopped people from losing a lot of money.
&ldquoWe have also been doing a lot of work on victim support. We need to make people aware of these crimes and tell people that there are many people out there who would not think twice about scamming you and taking your le savings away from you.
Ch insp McLean also stated there is a similar initiative running with post offices in the Borders.
And Police Scotland have held roadshows at a number of events as well as carrying out &lsquoreassurance visits&rsquo to the homes of previous victims.

title: selkirk-pharmacy-plans-to-convert-store-into-home
story:
PLANS have been submitted to Scottish Borders Council to convert a town centre building into a residential home.&nbsp
The building, at 10-12 Market Place in Selkirk, is currently used as a storage facility by the Lindsay and Gilmour Pharmacy which borders the building.&nbsp
Edinburgh-based Raimes, Clark and Co. Limited, which owns the Lindsay and Gilmour brand alongside Red Band Chemical Co. Limited, is planning on converting the building into two-storey home.&nbsp
The conversion, which is being designed by ABC Architecture, also of Edinburgh, will feature two bedrooms, set in an attic conversion, with downstairs lounge, kitchen and bathroom areas.&nbsp
The pharmacy&rsquos owners have applied for a change of use, from a store to a residential property, meaning that Selkirk&rsquos Market Place may be about to lose another commercial property.

title: heriot-landowner-applies-for-retrospective-planning-permission-for-horse-paddock
story:
A landowner is vying to get permission for an 1800 square metre horse paddock, despite the fact he&rsquos already built it.&nbsp
Ian Campbell, of Nettlingflat, near Heriot, has applied to Scottish Borders Council&rsquos planning department for retrospective planning permission for the exercise area after realising his mistake.&nbsp
His agents, Gateside Design, of Dunfermline, have written to council officers explaining the situation: &ldquoMy clients have created an outdoor riding arena on land at their property, Kepplegate, to provide a turnout and exercise area for their horses.&nbsp
&ldquoIt is exclusively for the private use of themselves and their family and not be operated as a commercial venture.&nbsp
&ldquoMy clients were not aware that planning permission was required for this.&nbsp
&ldquoThe site was formerly an open field/hard standing used to graze horses and park horse transport vehicles and other machinery.&nbsp
&ldquoThe site has been cut and filled to create the arena. Secure timber fencing has been erected to form an enclosure around the area.
If the retrospective planning application is refused, Scottish Borders Council can noty the applicant that they must remove the structure.&nbsp
If the applicant refuses to co-operate, the local authority can then begin formal legal proceedings to ensure the demolition of unauthorised works.&nbsp
A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: &ldquoFormal enforcement action is a last resort  all other recourse has failed and would be unlikely to be pursued until the outcome of any decision, including any appeal, is known.
&ldquoIn each instance, the council takes a view on an appropriate timeframe to  the land and property to its previous state, depending on the scale and nature of the works. There is no set timescale.

title: the-haining-says-i-do-to-weddings
story:
WEDDED bliss is coming to the banks of the Haining Loch.
Since the Palladian mansion, which dates back to the late 1800s, was gted to the people of Selkirkshire almost a decade ago it has gradually grown as a favourite venue for happy couples tying the knot.
But now the charitable trust who manage the Haining are looking out their hats to host their very first wedding fair.
On Sunday, September 16 the local professionals who make sure every wedding goes without a hitch will be on hand to guide bride-and-grooms-to-be.
A spokesman for The Haining Charitable Trust told us: "Our Wedding Fair will allow everyone the chance to meet our trusted suppliers and view this amazing venue that we have.
"The Haining offers the perfect wedding venue and the professional companies who can help make the day even more special will be available for a chat throughout Sunday."
The A-listed mansion, which is set in 150 acres of land, has undergone major renovations over the past seven or eight years.
And has become a hugely popular venue for events.
As well as being able to look around the venue itself, couples can meet florists, dress suppliers, groom outfitters, hair stylists, interior stylists, cake makers and even make-up artists during Sunday's event.
Ahead of Sunday's Wedding Fair the mansion will be dressed by Something Borrowed and flower displays will be provided by Stems.
The Haining Wedding Fair at the Haining on Sunday takes place between 11am and 4pm.

title: benny-presses-the-right-button-for-alans-shortlist-place
story:
LOVEABLE robot Benny hasn't just saved his planet from hairy, scary collectors... he's also gone and earned Galashiels author Alan Windram a shortlist place for a major national award.
One Button Benny is the wonderful story of heroes and the unlikely places they can be found.
Beautully illustrated by Lauder's Chloe Holwill-Hunter, the fun-packed book has already been thrilling three-to-six year olds throughout the summer.
And after being shortlisted for the 2019 Bookbug Picture Book Prize, One Button Benny will be entertaining thousands more Primary 1 pupils - with free copies of all three shortlisted books being handed out to children during Book Week Scotland.
Alan told us: "I am absolutely thrilled that One Button Benny has been shortlisted for the Bookbug Picture Book Prize.
"I had such fun working with Chloe as she brought Benny to le with her amazing illustrations.
"I hope that everyone enjoys reading the book as much as we enjoyed creating it.
"Like Benny the robot, I am literally over the moon."
Local children will have the chance to hear Alan read One Button Benny as well as perform the Zing, Zang, Zoom song when he takes to the Volunteer Hall stage in Galashiels on Wednesday for a Borders Book Festival event.
The shortlist for the 2019 Bookbug Picture Book Prize was announced last week, with the vote opening to schools and the public.
One Button Benny is joined by Emily Mackenzie's Eric Makes a Splash and I am Bat by Morag Hood on the shortlist.
The award was established to celebrate the most popular picture books by Scottish authors and illustrators, and is run by the Scottish Book Trust, with support from Browns Books for Students.
Susan Northey, who is director of Alan's Oban-based publisher Little Door Books, said: "I am delighted for Alan and Chloe that their wonderful book One Button Benny has been shortlisted for the Scottish Book Trust's 2019 Bookbug Picture Book Prize.
"As a small independent publisher we work hard to put out high-quality picture books that reflect the first-class writing talent of our authors, and also showcase the work of talented, but little known or newly graduated illustrators, with the ultimate aim of producing picture books that children will love.
"To be shortlisted for such a prestigious prize is a real honour."
During Book Week Scotland, which runs from November 19 to 25, all three shortlisted titles will be given to primary one pupils within the Bookbug Family Bag.
And pupils as well as their parents will be encouraged to vote for their favourite.
Marc Lambert, CEO of Scottish Book Trust, told us: "The Bookbug Picture Book Prize highlights some of the finest children&rsquos books in Scotland.
"We are delighted to work with Browns Books for Students to make this award possible and celebrate the wonderful authors and illustrators working in the picture book industry.
"We are sure children will love reading these stories and we look forward to finding out which is their favourite."
Videos of each author/illustrator reading and talking about their book are available at www.scottishbooktrust/bpbp
The winner of the Bookbug Picture Book Prize 2019 will be announced next January.
Alan Bett, Literature Officer at Creative Scotland, said: "We would like to congratulate the authors and illustrators of the three books shortlisted for the Bookbug Picture Book Prize.
"These might be some of the first works of fiction young readers enjoy for themselves, and an early step in a letime&rsquos love of books.
"Creative Scotland is delighted to support this initiative, through Scottish Book Trust, which lets the readers themselves vote for the winner."
For more information, the One Button Benny audiobook and downloadable songs visit www.littledoorbooks
Author Alan will be at the Volunteer Hall on Wednesday  from 10am.

title: v-is-for-vaselines-coming-to-galashiels
story:
PERHAPS these days The Vaselines are best known for being listed as one of Kurt Cobain's favourite bands.
And they are coming to play in Galashiels.
The Glasgow-based underground sensations were often cited by the late Nirvana singer as well his band covering Son of a Gun, Molly's Lips and Jesus Wants Me for a Sunbeam.
But away from the Cobain links The Vaselines are rightly regarded as one of Scotland's best-loved alternative bands from the late 80s and early 90s.
Formed in 1987 by Eugene Kelly and Frances McKee, they instantly became indie favourites with their pop-punk influenced songs.
Despite becoming hugely popular on home soil during their two years together neither their studio album Dum Dum or two singles reached the charts.
But they have enjoyed greater success since reforming a decade ago.
After a few performances at charity shows in Glasgow they began touring once more in 2008 and 2009.
The re-release of Enter the Vaselines led to a tour of the United States and a booking to play Primavera Sound Festival in Barcelona.
A stunning new album Sex With an X was released in 2010, followed four years later by equally fantastic V for Vaselines.
The Vaselines toured with the likes of Future Islands and Mogwai as their popularity soared.
And they have continued to sell-out venues all over the world with their infectious pop-punk sets.
The Vaselines will play MacArts in Galashiels on Saturday, December 1.
Tickets
, priced at &pound19, are available from www.ticketsource/boxoffice/select/JfyEQDYJaldv

title: third-time-lucky-as-chastity-returns-to-selkirk
story:
FOR anyone who hasn't yet caught the magnicent Chastity Brown it could be third time lucky later this month.
No one who was there will ever forget Chastity&rsquos first appearance at the String Jam Club back in January 2015.
In the club's 21 year history, she was the first ever artist to get a standing ovation after her first song.
It was a phenomenal reaction that continued throughout the evening.
Now String Jam promoter Allie Fox is thrilled to be welcoming Chastity back for her third appearance on the County Inn stage.
Allie told us: "This truly phenomenal Tennessee-born Americana-soul singer has been described as a 'rocking, rolling encyclopedia of roots music'.
"She blends the roots of gospel, soul, blues, folk and country, and her songs are raw, gritty intense and poetic.
"Her extraordinary voice will by turns hit you like a steam train and then touch you gently with a delicate feather."
Chastity grew up playing the saxophone and drums in a gospel church before she started to write and sing her own songs.
Now, with five acclaimed albums under her belt, her work has generated nothing short of a storm of attention and rave reviews.
Hailed by the music press, including American Songwriter, The Times, Paste Magazine, The Independent and many others, as well as appearing on 'Later ... With Jools Holland&rsquo her stardom continues to rise with accelerating speed.
Her fth album &lsquoSilhouette of Sirens&rsquo has been snapped up by major US label Red House Records and captures the quintessential sound of Chastity Brown: edgy, soulful, and intense.
Allie added: "The most powerful element of Chastity&rsquos music is her solo live performances.
"We can vouch for that first-hand.
"Chastity is an artist who feeds off the energy of the audience, and she gets better and better as that power and intensity builds over the evening.
"Your emotions will accelerate with her and you&rsquoll go with the flow, feeling a deep connection.
"Chastity&rsquos performance will be a restless and electrying, a night of soul-searching grit and grace, with a voice that can penetrate a brick wall with the intensity of its emotion.
"It doesn&rsquot get much better than this."
Chastity Brown plays the String Jam Club in Selkirk on Saturday, September 22.
Tickets
, priced at &pound15, are available from the County Hotel by phone 01750-705000 or from Eventbrite.
Doors open at 7.30pm.

title: call-for-curb-on-pavement-parking-in-innerleithen
story:
AN INNERLEITHEN resident is fed up with drivers parking on pavements in the town.
Frank Leonard says he is sick of inconsiderate motorists leaving their vehicles outside his door in the High Street.
And the retired bus driver says he has raised his concerns &ndash but they have fallen on deaf ears.
He told the Peeblesshire News: &ldquoThis problem has been going on for as long as I can remember and I have been living here for 31 years.
&ldquoI have been to a number of people to try and get the problem resolved. I have raised my concerns at Innerleithen Community Council, with the police and with the council.
&ldquoThe police told me it is not illegal to park on the pavements, but it is to drive on them.
&ldquoOver the past year or so there have been trucks, tractors and slurry tankers pulling up outside my house.
&ldquoWhen they are parked there, it makes it very dficult for people with buggies or wheelchairs to get past.
&ldquoNot only that, I suffer with COPD [Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease] and  I open the doors or windows, the exhaust fumes coming from the vehicles, come into the house.
Mr Leonard wrote to Scottish Borders Council leader Shona Haslam  last year.
He added: &ldquoIn December I had a meeting with Councillor Haslam at my house.
&ldquoShe said she was looking into it, but unfortunately there are still vehicles parking on the pavement.
Cllr Haslam has now said she will ask the recently-launched Community Action Team  to monitor the situation.
She told us: &ldquoPavement parking continues to be an issue in many of our town centres, it is a nuisance and causes disruption for shoppers and residents.
&ldquoWe have invested an additional &pound260,000 to employ more police officers in the Borders who are targeting this irresponsible parking.
&ldquoI will request that they have a focus on Innerleithen High Street in the next few months.

title: gp-saddles-up-to-retrace-selkirk-doctors-epic-cycle-of-1916
story:
HISTORY repeated itself in Selkirk last week, when retired local GP John Wilson undertook the same 87-mile cycle ride made in 1916 by the town&rsquos legendary medical practitioner, Dr John Muir, at the age of 71.
Dr Muir served the medical needs of Selkirk from 1867-1928, becoming one of the local community&rsquos most respected and well-loved figures.
Not only was he a keen cyclist, he kept a meticulous record of his family le and his day-to-day dealings with the public in a series of diaries.
In 2014, some 40 of Dr Muir&rsquos diaries were presented by his descendants to the Scottish Borders Archive &amp Local History Service, and these were then transcribed by staff at Hawick&rsquos Heritage Hub.
Two years later, at the request of Live Borders, Selkirk playwright and actor John Nichol used material from the diaries as the basis for his one-man, one-act play, Dr John Stewart Muir: The Beloved Doctor.
Taking the title role himself, John&rsquos play received a rapturous reception at its premiere in the town&rsquos County Hotel in February, 2017.
One scene features Dr Muir recounting an ambitious cycle ride he took to Moffat in 1916, ing via Boreland, Eskdalemuir and Ettrickbridge.
It is this ride that retired local GP John Wilson retraced last Wednesday, following the exact route described by Dr Muir.
&ldquoI always thought it would be amazing to recreate that ride, John told the Border  this week, &ldquoso I&rsquom just so happy that John Wilson was able to do it.
Just as Dr Muir had done before him, John stopped off at Moffat&rsquos Buccleuch Arms Hotel, where he was welcomed by director Polly Smith, while on the  journey he stopped at the Cross Keys in Ettrickbridge, where he was given a glass of water by owner Trevor Logan.
Dr Wilson&rsquos encounters throughout the day were filmed by retired Selkirk journalist John Smail, who is making a documentary entitled A Souter&rsquos Year, covering all aspects of le in Selkirk and the Valleys during 2018.
At the end of Wednesday&rsquos ride Dr Wilson, himself an extremely proficient road cyclist, said he&rsquod thoroughly enjoyed the experience.
He added: &ldquoThe landscape is spectacular and it makes you appreciate the history and cultural importance of this area.
&ldquoI&rsquom sure Dr Muir would have had similar thoughts and feelings.
"I can&rsquot imagine that he didn&rsquot appreciate the cultural background of the Borders, and how important its history and traditions are in forming the people who live here.

title: inspectors-highlight-poor-layout-not-enough-staff-and-too-many-accidents-at-sbcs-pilot-nursery
story:
ONE of the region's pilot nurseries for delivering increased free childcare has come in for criticism by inspectors.
Langlee Primary School Nursery is one of seven early learning centres across the Borders trialling an increase in funded early learning and childcare from 600 to 1140 hours.
By 2020 the additional hours should be available across the whole Borders.
Education bosses at Scottish Borders Council believe Langlee Nursery is capable of catering for up to 100 three-, four- and eligible two-year-old children.
But experts from the Care Inspectorate found the centre, which is part of the new &pound10 million Langlee Primary School, is struggling to cope.
Inspectors weren't happy with the lay-out of the new nursery and highlighted the 'high number of accidents' that had happened as well as a shortage of staff.
A spokeswoman for the Care Inspectorate said: "Providing lunch for a large number of children provided a signicant organisational challenge and resulted in a poor experience for children.
"Staff tried hard to make lunch positive and did ensure children had something to eat and drink but opportunities for independence and children's choices were limited.
"On the day of our visit it was apparent that the space allocated to the nursery was not working well.
"The quality, layout and aesthetic appeal of play activities for children over three needed to be signicantly improved.
"There had been a high number of accidents in the nursery and we asked senior staff to audit these to see  there was a pattern to time, event or children involved."
Langlee Nursery is made up of two classrooms and a central atrium area.
And most children have access to an outdoor play area as well.
Parents praised staff in their responses to questionnaires sent out by the inspectors.
But the inspectors also found problems with the turnover of staff and the need for bank workers to fill in.
The spokeswoman added: "There were acknowledged challenges in the staff team.
"The nursery had increased in the number of children quite signicantly in the last year and the staffing had lacked continuity.
"Additional staff needed to be employed to ensure the children's needs could be met and this was being addressed."
While previous inspections of Langlee Nursery by the Care Inspectorate led to gradings of either 'very good' or 'good' the latest inspection found the quality of environment, of staffing, and of management as only 'adequate' with only the level of care and support still deemed 'good'.
A spokesperson for Scottish Borders Council said: "The council has already taken signicant steps following the care inspectorate visit and has addressed a number of the matters raised, for example improving lunch routines.
"SBC takes very seriously any recommendations made during these inspections and regularly monitors progress.
"We are confident that the matters raised in the report are being addressed and additional support will be provided to ensure good progress is achieved quickly."

title: wallace-or-scott-selkirk-to-decide-on-new-signs
story:
PLANS are being drawn up for new tourism signage at Selkirk&rsquos four main entrances &ndash but community leaders can't decide whether to go with William Wallace of Sir Walter Scott.
Councillors and business leaders are investigating dferent designs and wording to use for attracting motorists to stop off in the Royal Burgh.
And the town&rsquos Business Improvement District  officers are currently probing the ious options.
Local councillor Caroline Penman said: &ldquoAlong with Selkirk BIDs we are looking at what the new signs should say to encourage people to stop and explore &ndash should it be the Old Town Centre, William Wallace or Sir Walter Scott?
&ldquoThe signs would pinpoint people towards attractions and also where to park.
Sir Walter Scott dispensed justice from the bench in Selkirk for almost 30 years.
And, as well as a town centre statue to celebrate the connection, his courtroom has been transformed into a museum to the world-famous author and poet.
But William Wallace&rsquos connections to the town are every bit as strong.
It is widely believed that he was declared  of Scotland at a medieval kirk just a short walk from the town centre at the height of his Braveheart battles with England.
A geophysics survey carried out two years ago at the ruins of the town's 18th Century Auld Kirk revealed remains of a medieval chapel &ndash believed to be the legendary Kirk o' the Forest.
But a third choice of promoting Selkirk's historical town centre, which has many closes and alleyways dating back to 17th and 18th century, as well as having links with nearby battles at Philiphaugh and Flodden, is also being considered.
Selkirk Community Council member Jim Stillie said: &ldquoAll we have to sell to tourists is our history and we should make them aware of what we have.

title: joy-as-eastgate-fundraising-target-achieved
story:
AFTER weeks of fundraising, Peebles' Eastgate Theatre has finally reached its &pound70,000 target.
The urgent call was made at the beginning of July to collect the money in just two months.
And on Thursday, August 30, thanks to the efforts of hundreds of people, companies in Tweeddale and many other local organisations, the ambitious target was reached.
The fundraising effort has now triggered the release of a European Leader grant of &pound150,000, along with a combination of other grants, which means that the theatre now has the budget to transform its auditorium.
The revamp forms phase one of the 'Building on success' strategy to develop the building and make it more customer friendly and fit to meet increasing demand.
If the plans go to schedule, by the end of summer 2019 the auditorium will be developed to designs by Simpson &amp Brown Architects.
A raft of improvements will be made, including existing retractable seating replaced with new, better padded seats and increased legroom, plus aisle seats fitted with hand grabs, to help customers move up and down the steps more easily.
The current balcony seats that provide a restricted view of the stage will be replaced by around 24 new seats on diagonally stepped platforms.
They will offer a full view of the stage when two sections of solid balcony are replaced with steel rail and glass panels.
Also, new swivel stools, in the section of the balconies closest to the stage, will allow the theatre to offer some seats at a reduced ticket price.
Low level safety lighting will be introduced into the new side balconies, and new heating ducts will be installed to deliver hot air at floor level.
Sir David Younger, chair of the Eastgate board of directors said: &ldquoThe Board would like to thank most sincerely the Eastgate staff, the Friends of the Eastgate and all donors who rose magnicently to the challenge of raising a sizeable sum of money in a very short space of time.
&ldquoThe theatre was first developed in 2004 by the efforts of the local community and it is heartening for all of us to realise that all these years later it is still so valued.
&ldquoBy levering the European Leader grant the local fundraising has made a huge impact locally.
&ldquoThis, combined with the success of general manager Caroline Adam in attracting other signicant capital grants will help to ensure that the people of Tweeddale and much further afield have an arts venue well equipped to meet future needs.
Donations to the appeal came in all shapes and sizes ranging from a little boy who put 50p of his pocket money into the donations box in the foyer to an American couple who transferred a four-figure sum. A bullock donated by local farmer Robert Barr now has Muchacoo  on his passport after dozens of visitors to the Peebles Agricultural show each paid &pound5 to name him.
All of the money raised will go towards the development of the Eastgate Theatre building.
Discussions are already underway about progressing to phase two which will improve and reconfigure the foyer/caf&eacute areas.

title: sheriff-orders-gala-woman-to-hand-over-car-keys
story:
A GALASHIELS woman has been ordered to give up her car keys after being accused of two drink driving offences in the space of two months.
June McKain has been told she cannot drive a vehicle until the outcome of her trial in November.
The 58-year-old of Ladhope Crescent, appeared from custody at Selkirk Sherf Court where she pleaded not guilty to a charge of driving with a breath/alcohol count of 42 microgrammes - the legal limit being 22 - on Saturday.
She was released on bail which had the special conditions of not driving and giving up her car keys.
McKain was already waiting trial on a charge of driving while more than four times the legal limit.
The offence is alleged to have been committed in the Asda Car Park in Galashiels on July 19.
An intermediate hearing has been fixed for October 22.

title: sign-up-for-deaf-comedy-tour-as-two-borders-dates-revealed
story:
AFTER a sell-out run at the Edinburgh Fringe, a two-time Scottish Comedian of the Year finalist is heading to the Borders.
Ray Bradshaw will take his critically acclaimed stand up show Deaf Comedy Fam on a four-month UK tour, which includes a two stops in the region, one at Peebles&rsquo Eastgate Theatre on October 4, and another at Galashiels&rsquo MacArts Centre on November 2.
Around one in six people suffer from hearing loss, two of those people are Ray&rsquos parents.&nbsp
Ray&rsquos show presents a first for stand-up comedy.
He tells his stories in English as well as his first language, British Sign Language.&nbsp
Growing up with deaf parents, Ray has many hilarious and eye-opening tales to share &ndash including the time he learned that Santa wasn&rsquot deaf.
Dubbed as a &ldquotruly unique show, the gig represents a desire of Ray&rsquos to make the world of comedy more accessible for deaf people &ndash  only to take the pressure off himself when it comes to making his parents laugh.&nbsp
Deaf Comedy Fam debuted at the Glasgow International Comedy Festival and completely sold out, before moving to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for a critically-acclaimed, fully sold out run.&nbsp
Ray has numerous radio credits under his belt with BBC Scotland and BBC Radio 4, has supported Irish comedian Ardal O&rsquoHanlon on his recent tour and is a regular guest on Frankie Boyle and Friends.
Having launched his comedy career in 2008, Bradshaw has quickly established himself as one of the brightest and most exciting acts on the UK comedy circuit.&nbsp
A two-time Scottish Comedian of the Year finalist, Bradshaw had a sell-out run with I Dare Ray To&hellip in 2015, as well as two sell-out seasons at Adelaide Fringe in 2015 and 2016.&nbsp
In the past year, he has performed at Adelaide Fringe, Melbourne International Comedy Festival, Singapore Fringe and the Kuala Lumpur Comedy Carnival.
For Ray&rsquos performance at the Eastgate, tickets are &pound15, &pound13, &pound6 for under 15s and can be bought at 
www.eastgatearts
.
For his show at Galashiels&rsquos MacArts visit 
www.ticketsource/macarts

title: double-delight-as-us-and-oz-come-together-at-st-boswells-live
story:
LATER this month St Boswells Live will be hosting a sublime event co-headlined between Aussie and resident Borderer Jenny Biddle, and USA west coast performer John Craigie.
Both of them are consummate songwriters and musicians, telling tales ranging from the heartbreaking to the outright hilarious, each in their own very dferent styles.
If Tracy Chapman married Joni Mitchell but then had a saucy love affair with Ani Dranco, you&rsquod get Jenny Biddle.
With six albums under her belt and an iTunes chart-topping single, indie folk/blues songsmith, Jenny wraps herself around her guitar, and like a marriage between body and instrument, she commands her instrument to talk &ldquowith uncommon skill and absolute self-assurance .
Her audience is compelled to join her on a voyage of passion and story in song.
Acoustic guitar-maker, proficient pianist, recovering chocoholic, and harmonica squawker, our Aussie singer is now based in sunny Scotland, touring internationally, and practising the art of making a woodstove fire with wet wood.
For this evening Jenny will be recording a live album which the audience will be a part of, something truly not to be missed.
Jenny explained why she relocated to the Scottish Borders: I" moved over for love - the love of weather - actually I met my we four years ago while busking at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and moved to be here with her.
"We got married on the Eildons last year!
"My mother originated from Scotland as a ten-pound Pom - it&rsquos interesting to come back to her roots."
Recording a live album at her local village hall is something Jenny is excited about.
She explained: "It&rsquos time for a new album.
"I was impressed with Keith Farnish&rsquos recordings from past gigs, and I like the idea of stripping my songs back and capturing the playfulness and spontaneity of a live show.
"St Boswells Live will make for a terric audience to singalong with and they&rsquoll become backing singers for the album!
"I love engaging the audience and feed off it, even a bit of light heckling from them mixes things up.
"Once I had a lady crawl on the floor and bite me on the leg while performing in Melbourne &ndash those kinds of audience members are less preferable. I can&rsquot wait to capture the show live this month. Who knows what will happen."
Renowned for his eloquent Americana style, engaging live shows, and off-the-cuff clever observations, co-headliner John Craigie carries on the legacy of classic singer-songwriters, while blazing a trail of his own.
Recently, that trail twisted and turned into new territory for the Portland, Oregon performer who The Stranger appropriately dubbed, &ldquothe lovechild of John Prine and Mitch Hedberg.
His music speaks loud to both audiences and fellow artists. Todd Snider notably hand-delivered a gt on-stage, and Chuck Norris has sent fan mail.
His fth full- album, No Rain, No Rose boasted two collaborations with Gregory Alan Isakov, namely Highway Blood and I Am Calornia.
As No Rain, No Rose landed, he caught the attention of none other than Jack Johnson.
Through a serendipitous series of events, Craigie&rsquos 2016 live effort Capricorn in Retrograde landed in Johnson&rsquos car stereo during a Calornia coastal road trip.
Shortly after, Jack reached out and Craigie soon found himself onstage for 12 shows during Johnson&rsquos 2017 summer tour, and again in the summer of 2018.
Doors open at St Boswells Village Hall on Saturday, September 29 at 7.30pm.
Tickets
are available in advance priced just &pound12  from St Boswells Old Post Office or online from www.stboswellslive

title: uk-economy-unprepared-for-fourth-industrial-revolution-john-mcdonnell
story:
John McDonnell has claimed the financial crises has left Britain&rsquos economy dangerously unprepared for the fourth industrial revolution.
Speaking ahead of a protest calling for reform of the financial sector outside the Royal Exchange building in London, the shadow chancellor said the revenue generated by the city is being squandered.
He told the Press Association: &ldquoI&rsquom worried that the City of London isn&rsquot listening and what we have is a system whereby the productive elements of the economy that are creating wealth is being erted into property speculation and not addressing the real need and the fundamentals of our economy.
&ldquoWe&rsquore facing the fourth industrial revolution and we&rsquove got the lowest investment in robots in the G7, and we&rsquore still not investing in the schools we need.
&ldquoWe need to harness the resources of the finance sector in this country to make sure it&rsquos invested in long-term, patient, stable investment, and I&rsquom not seeing that happen.
He said among his biggest concerns for Britain&rsquos future were household debt and the fact that wages are still below the level they were in 2010.
However, Mr McDonnell said he welcomed the news that Mark Carney will be remaining in post until the end of January 2020.
He said: &ldquoI have a good working relationship with Mark Carney, I&rsquom glad he&rsquos remaining, it will give us the stability and it will enable us then when we go into a government we can work with a banker we have confidence in.
SNP MP Kirsty Blackman addresses the protesters 
He denied that calling for greater regulation sends the message that Labour wants to punish the city for the financial crisis, saying: &ldquoI think demonstrations like this are sending out the message that what we need is reform in the financial sector and that will provide us with the long-term stability that we need. Unless we address these issues, we are simply storing up problems for the future.
Mr McDonnell said that the possibility of quitting the EU would be disastrous for the economy and that a Labour government&rsquos number one priority would be securing a deal.
He said: &ldquoConsistently now, we&rsquove been meeting with business leaders, trade union leaders, representatives from the city, asset managers and bankers, I met with representatives from Goldman Sachs last week, all the messages are the same &ndash &lsquoGet a deal that protects jobs and the economy&rsquo, and  they can&rsquot, the message is &lsquomove aside. We&rsquoll do the negotiations&rsquo.
In his speech, he renewed Labour&rsquos 2017 election pledge for a transaction tax between financial institutions and the establishment of strategic investment pot for banks and business leaders to work with government to generate wealth.
Protesters lead the calls for financial reform 
He added that Labour would crack down on legal tax avoidance, saying: &ldquoIn the last general election people accused me of having a magic money tree.
&ldquoWell, I&rsquove found it &ndash it&rsquos in the Cayman Islands. We&rsquore going to dig it up and bring it here.
He continued: &ldquo[To banks] the message is this &ndash you will get a decent rate of  but we are not going to be ripped off any more &ndash ripped off by speculation, privatisation, job cuts and exploitation of workers.
The event was organised by pressure group Change Finance and Positive Money, and among the speakers were Zita Holbourne, of civil rights group Barac UK, and Green MEP Molly Scott Cato.
Also among the speakers was SNP MP Kirsty Blackman, who boasted of her party&rsquos reforms to welfare, taxation and social housing.
She said: &ldquoIn Scotland,  you look at what&rsquos happening, even with one arm behinds its back &ndash because the Scottish Government doesn&rsquot have all the power &ndash you can see what a government on the left can actually do.

title: philippines-faces-trail-of-destruction-as-typhoon-mangkhut-batters-country
story:
Typhoon Mangkhut has lashed the northern Philippines with destructive winds and heavy rain that set off landslides and destroyed homes on Saturday, leaving at least 12 people dead.
The most ferocious typhoon to hit the disaster-prone Philippines this year slammed ashore before dawn in Cagayan province on the north-eastern tip of Luzon island.
China and the Philippines agreed to postpone a visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi that was to start on Sunday due to the onslaught, which caused nearly 150 flights &ndash a third of them international &ndash to be cancelled and halted sea travel.
Presidential adviser Francis Tolentino said the 12 died mostly in landslides and houses that got pummelled by the storm&rsquos fierce winds and rain.
Among the dead were an infant and a two-year-old child who died with their parents after the couple refused to immediately evacuate from their high-risk community in a mountain town in Nueva Vizcaya province, Mr Tolentino said.
A family shares a meal inside a temporary evacuation centre in Tuguegarao city 
President Rodrigo Duterte has assigned Mr Tolentino to help co-ordinate disaster response. Mr Tolentino said at least two other people were missing and that the death toll could climb to at least 16 once other casualty reports were veried.
Mayor Mauricio Domogan said at least three people died and six others were missing in the mountain city of Baguio after strong winds and rain destroyed several houses and set off landslides, which also blocked roads to the popular vacation destination.
Authorities were verying the drownings of three people, including two children who reportedly died as the typhoon approached.
About 70 men reportedly ed to their coastal village in Cagayan to check on their homes as the typhoon drew closer Friday, but Mr Tolentino said he had received no report of the men figuring in an accident.
Mangkhut&rsquos sustained winds weakened to 105mph, with gusts of up to 160mph, after it sliced north-west across Luzon before blowing out to the South China Sea, aiming at Hong Kong and elsewhere in southern China.
About 87,000 people evacuated from high-risk areas of the Philippines. Mr Tolentino and other officials advised them not to  home until the danger had passed.
A man uses a water container to shield him from rain in Tuguegarao city 
&ldquoIt&rsquos still a le-and-death situation, defence secretary Delfin Lorenzana said, citing past drownings in swollen rivers in mountain provinces after storms had passed.
Storm warnings remained in effect in 10 northern provinces, including Cagayan, which could still be lashed by devastating winds, forecasters said. Thousands of people in the typhoon&rsquos path had been evacuated.
At daybreak in Cagayan&rsquos capital, Tuguegarao, Associated Press journalists saw a severely damaged public market, its roof ripped apart and wooden stalls and tarpaulin canopies in disarray. Outside a popular shopping centre, debris was scattered everywhere and government workers cleared roads of fallen trees.
Many stores and houses were damaged but most residents remained indoors as occasional gusts sent small pieces of tin sheets and other debris flying dangerously.
The Tuguegarao airport terminal was badly damaged, its roof and glass windows shattered by strong winds that also sent chairs, tables and papers flipping about inside, Mr Lorenzana said.
A government damage assessment was under way except in areas still being battered by winds and rain. Two air force C-130 cargo planes and 10 helicopters were on standby in the capital Manila to help transport rescuers and aid supplies.
More than five million people were at risk from the storm, which the Hawaii-based Joint Typhoon Warning Centre downgraded from a super typhoon. Mangkhut, however, was still punching powerful winds and gusts equivalent to a Category 4 Atlantic hurricane.

title: sturgeon-urged-to-announce-plans-for-second-independence-referendum
story:
Campaigners have called on Nicola Sturgeon to announce plans next month for a second independence referendum.
Several hundred people, many waving saltires, attended the This Time It&rsquos Yes rally at George Square organised by Hope Over Fear, compered by former MSP Tommy Sheridan.
The politician, who was jailed for perjury in 2011, told the crowd he wanted the First Minister to use her mandate for a second independence referendum.
&ldquoIn 2016 the Scottish Parliament elections were held and the SNP were quite clear, they sought a mandate for Indyref2 and they won it, he said.
&ldquoThe Scottish Parliament voted to hold Indyref2 in September 2018 or March 2019.
He added: &ldquoWe can go in March next year. Please Nicola, sound the bell. Fire the starting pistol.
&ldquoPlease Nicola Sturgeon, you&rsquove done a good job so far, put yourself at the head of this campaign &hellip and on the 7th of October in Glasgow&rsquos SECC please stand up and ignite the passion across Scotland by announcing loud and clear we&rsquore going to use the mandate.
It&rsquos happening! 
pic.twitter/Ks5BBU2lKK
&mdash Hope Over Fear  
September 15, 2018
Other speakers at the event included Western Isles SNP MP Angus MacNeil and former Scottish cabinet minister Alex Neil.
Mr Neil said: &ldquoThe time has come for us to go out and evangelise how much better le would be  we make our parliament an independent parliament.
He said a &ldquovery minimum of 55% of independence supporters was needed to ensure winning the second referendum.
&ldquoI pledge myself, and I hope everyone here pledges themselves, to do everything we need to do in the next month and the next few years, to get Indyref2 and to win Indyref2.
Campaigners had planned to show the film Braveheart at the start of the rally but the screening did not go ahead.
Independence campaign group Saor Alba organised a march to the event and the group&rsquos George Kempik said the turnout at the rally had been &ldquodisapointing, but vowed they would continue.
He said: &ldquoI have children and grandchildren, and for me this is about them. I&rsquove been fighting for independence since the original referendum for devolution in Scotland in 1979 and nothing I&rsquove seen then has ever changed my mind.
&ldquoThe rallies are just a reminder to everybody. They&rsquove got to keep happening.
Charles Archibald, 42, from Stirling, attended the rally with his family to show his support for the independence movement.
He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos not going to go away, it&rsquos never going to go away.

title: a-landmark-patrol-for-borders-street-pastors
story:
LAST Saturday saw the Borders Street Pastors complete their 150th patrol in the region.
Team leader Fiona Corbett led the patrol in Galashiels with Billy Caswell and Steve MacDonald.
Street Pastors come from all over the Borders and in addition to the weekly Saturday night patrol in Galashiels, are also out once a month from 11pm until around 3.30am in Hawick.
In addition, teams have been present at a number of Common Riding events and Rugby 7s.
Using the principles of listening, caring and helping, the team patrol the central area of the town, offering assistance to those in need and helping people who may have found themselves in a vulnerable position.
Flip flops continue to be a popular item that the team carry, with over 1,200 pairs issued since 2016 and with over 7000 lolly pops given away in that time as well, Street Pastor patrols are never quiet.
Street Pastors come from many denominations of the Christian community in the Borders and can be contacted at borders@streetpastors.org.uk

title: pope-tells-mafia-to-change-its-ways
story:
Pope Francis has appealed to the mafia to renounce their quests for power and money.
Francis was visiting Sicily to honour a priest killed by mob henchmen for trying to protect youths from the clutches of organised crime.
The day-long trip by Francis to the Mediterranean island where the Cosa Nostra is rooted marked the 25th anniversary of the assassination of the Reverend Giuseppe &ldquoPino Puglisi.
Only by giving our le do we conquer evil. This is what Don Pino Puglisi teaches: he lived to spread goodness.    
&mdash Pope Francis  
September 15, 2018
Puglisi was declared a martyr by the Vatican and beatied in 2013, the last formal step before possible sainthood.
Francis paid tribute to the priest, who worked to keep unemployed youths in a poor neighbourhood of Palermo from turning to local Mafia bosses for jobs like pushing drugs.
The papal pilgrimage came amid revelations about priests and bishops who sexually abused children or connived to protect the abusers in ious nations.
Tens of thousands of people cheered Francis at an open air Mass held in the late morning at an esplanade along the port city&rsquos waterfront.
A large banner carried by young people in the crowd as Francis was driven by in his white popemobile read &ldquoLet&rsquos renew the church.
Pope Francis is driven through the crowd as a large banner reading &lsquoLet&rsquos renew the church&rsquo is visible 
Pressure is building on Francis to say what he knew about the sexual misconduct of US prelate Theodore McCarrick, who was recently stripped of his cardinal&rsquos rank by the pope.
Francis drew applause as he told the crowd: &ldquoIf the Mafioso litany is, &lsquoyou don&rsquot know who I am,&rsquo the Christian one is &lsquoI need you.&rsquo If the Mafia threat is &lsquoyou will pay me,&rsquo the Christian prayer is &lsquoLord, help me to love.'
&ldquoThus I say to the Mafiosi: change, brothers and sisters. Quit thinking about yourselves and your money, Francis continued in his homily.
&ldquoYou know, a funeral shroud doesn&rsquot have pockets. You can&rsquot take it with you, Francis said of organised crime&rsquos ill-gained wealth from drug and arms trafficking, extortion and betting and prostitution rackets.
&ldquoYou give le to others, not take it away. You can&rsquot believe in God and hate your brother, take away le with hatred, Francis said.

title: campbeltown learns about the air ace of argyll
story: A collection of artefacts belonging to an Argyll airship captain and First World War submarine hunter has landed in Kintyre.The &#8216Air Ace of Argyll &#8211 Airships in the Great War and the Story of Major J G Struthers&#8217 exhibition in Campbeltown Library features a trove of items belonging to the late Major Jim Struthers, formerly of Ardmaddy Estate, near Oban.The items, including a dummy shell, gas goggles, badges and medals, a unorm and original airship banners and propellers, were collated, over the course of a year, by Eleanor McKay, bibliographic and local studies librarian at Live Argyll, after a conversation with Major Struthers&#8217 son Charles.&#8216He said he had &#8216one or two things&#8217 belonging to his late father,&#8217 Eleanor explained. &#8216It turned out to be eight boxes full of artefacts that we&#8217re still going through now.&#8216It&#8217s one of the best collections from the First World War that we have seen.&#8217There are parts of shot-down airships, a parachute, fragments of a radiator from a zeppelin and much more.Accompanying the artefacts, are photographs, many taken by Major Struthers himself, documenting his personal le and military career, as well as the history of airships.Major Struthers, who was mentioned in dispatches, was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross, with two bars later added, for his missions with the Royal Naval Air Service, which amalgamated with the British Army&#8217s Royal Flying Core to become the Royal Air Force in 1918.Major Struthers was recognised for flying more hours than any other airship pilot during the war.Aged 52 by the time the Second World War broke out, Major Struthers was too old to serve but he was in the Royal Observer Corps, his patch stretching from Sutherland to Machrihanish.&#8216It&#8217s local to Oban but it&#8217s an Argyll story,&#8217 said Eleanor. &#8216Major Struthers was actually based in Cornwall during the war.&#8217Diana Manning, from Drumlemble but originally from Cornwall, attended the exhibition&#8217s Campbeltown opening to find out more about the Cornish history, and found it &#8216fascinating&#8217.During her opening speech, Eleanor said: &#8216I think this is an area of World War One that people don&#8217t really think about.&#8216They think about later aircraft, especially in World War Two, but I don&#8217t think they know the role they had in World War One.&#8217Councillor Donald Kelly, who attended the opening, said he thought it was essential to engage with local school children: &#8216It&#8217s important that youngsters today know what went on in the past &#8211 especially involving someone from Argyll.&#8217The exhibition, which was launched in Oban in July, will be in Campbeltown until September 29, before moving on to Helensburgh and Dunoon.Councillor John Armour, Campbeltown&#8217s library supervisor Christine McPhee, Eleanor McKay and Councillor Donald Kelly at the exhibition&#8217s opening. story: Woodworkers and artists became guitarists and violinists to spur on a Wild West-themed Clachan celebration of local crafts, industry, culture and music flowing.Through the day, last Saturday, title: down memory lane september 7 2018
story: A century ago, in 1918, when racquets were made of wood, strung with animal gut and required presses to stop them warping, the captain and officers, of Australian depot ship HMS Platypus, presented a cup to Campbeltown Lawn Tennis club.The following year the HMS Platypus Cup became the club&#8217s mixed doubles championship&#8217s coveted trophy and names began to be inscribed.As with any weather dependent sport there were years when the championship was not played, or perhaps there were not enough ladies and gents to run a mixed doubles competition.If the teams were always picked from a hat, the method used currently, it would explain why partnerships did not endure, unless by luck, though one strong player may win successively.The cup&#8217s first winners in 1919 were: Mrs Chapman and Mr R. Y. Maxtone, the following year Mr Maxtone partnered Miss B Strang.1921 must have been a strange year for mixed doubles. The winner is inscribed as P. S. MacNair without a partner. Sometimes it can be a struggle to get teams, so perhaps MacNair played singles against a doubles pair.In 1922 honours were taken by Miss C. K. MacNish and Mr E. Armour. In 1923 a dferent pair emerged Miss J. I. McKersie and Mr A. G. MacKelvie.Miss B. Strang ed, partnered by Mr L. Edwards in 1924. In 1925 a christian name is inscribed for the first time, when, Bella Strang, taking her third win, was partnered by  Mr C. MacTaggart.Mrs W. McKersie and Mr C. McTaggart won in 1926 and Miss S. Colville and Mr R. W. Greenlees in 1927.Mrs Mary MacFadyen, was the next winner to gain the christian name honour in 1928 and she did not have take three wins.The first and possibly only gentleman to see his christian name used, was the prolic 1950&#8217s winner, Rev. G. Stuart Cameron, he was part of the winning duo five times.Ann Ogilvie began a run of success in 2007 and this year Dorothy Gray was a finalist who first made it onto the cup in 1992.Early winners of the HMS Platypus Cup. 25_c35memorylane04Australian depot ship HMS Platypus. title: letter snp plans for scotland
story: The SNP’s plan for Scotland signals a major boost for jobs and the economy in Argyll and Bute, including an additional £7 billion infrastructure investment in schools, hospitals, transport and digital connectivity over the next five years.We are continuing the major reforms in our health, education and justice systems over the course of 2018/19.There is signicant £250 million extra funding for mental health services, increased support for teachers, head teachers, parents and pupils, as well as a major package of reforms for the justice system, increasing support for the victims of crime and their families.With Scottish exports up 12 per cent &#8211 the fastest growth in the UK – a £20m National Exports Plan this year will ensure Argyll and Bute’s businesses thrive.Despite Brexit, we will ensure Scotland remains an attractive place to live and work.We will provide advice and support for those EU citizens, already living in Argyll and Bute, who are dealing with the Tory government’s unfair plans to charge them for the right to live and work here.Our global climate change ambition will continue to be matched by realistic action, with £1billion funding in low carbon and public transport during the next year.Michael Russell,MSP for Argyll and Bute.

title: regeneration through books and a bridge
story: Scotland has so many cultural and trade links to Ireland it is amazing a bridge has not been built.It is possible to travel 972 miles from Stockholm to Brussels without ever using a ferry.Yet the only link from Scotland &#8211 north of Cairnryan, which itself is not on a motorway &#8211 to Ireland, is via a 12-person, Kintyre Express RIB from Campbeltown.The contrast could not be more stark. The two great nations are separated by a channel, 14 miles wide, with no road transport leaving a choice between flying or travelling on a super size speedboat.Book festivals are springing up in many Argyll places yet Kintyre which has a rich literary tradition is the poor relation.That may change  there is a will to create and run a MOK Book or similar.The Malts Festival has become well established.Perhaps it would be good to nurse a dram and discuss a good read &#8211 and it is more likely than a £20 billion bridge.

title: thought for the week september 7 2018
story: Barak Obama said this of her: &#8216In the example she set both as an artist and a citizen, Aretha embodied those most revered virtues of forgiveness and reconciliation, while the music she made captured some of our deepest human desires, namely affection and respect.&#8216And through her voice, her own voice, Aretha lted those of millions, empowering and inspiring the vulnerable, the downtrodden, and everyone who may have just needed a little love&#8217.Similarly in Washington thousands came to pay respect to Senator John McCain.Among the many tributes, Barak Obama, despite their political dferences, said this: &#8216John understood that our security and our influence was won not just by our military might, not just by our wealth, not just by our ability to bend others to our will, but from our capacity to inspire others with our adherence to a set of universal values &#8211 like rule of law and human rights &#8211 and an insistence on the God-given dignity of every human being.&#8217Two very high profile funerals which were beamed to thousands world wide, touched many.However the bigger the funeral, no greater the love or the respect or the grief.I am immensely touched by the quiet dignity of our own country funerals as people gather in the wee church they call home.People have been there many times before and will come again, as long as folk shall live – and die.They come because of love.Let&#8217s make love great again – for love is stronger than death.This is the promise from God to us all.
